text: If Julia compiles to the LLVM, and static compilation, type checking, and manual memory management will soon be allowed, then what is the point of Rust?  A built-in linter could check, between statements guaranteeing that all the i’s have been dotted and t’s crossed within, and then do everything Rust does but with better semantics.

text: Where did you get that Julia will have type checking and first class manual memory management?

elements.text: Where did you get that Julia will have type checking and first class manual memory management?

text:
You are massively overestimatimg how close to real those things are.

There has been vague thought about statically compiling Julia for ages, but we are not really anywhere near having something generally useful or easy to use for that.

Type-checking Julia is semantically impossible.
So at best it would be some kind of linting that is allowed to fail.

Manual memory management is not even a fully fleshed out idea.
Keno is thinking like "at some point soon we should do *something* that lets us better track the lifetime of memory, something we could Implement ref-counting and some kind of ownership on top of, particularly so we can have more tight control over GPU memory."

text:
Rust has a totally different philosophy to Julia.
And a total different audience.
Rust is super well established at these things now.
Julia might well be able to do some of these things in 2-5 years.
But at that time rust will be 2-5 years better of that kind of things still.
